Template.Description: Elevate your LinkedIn game. Cohesive's LinkedIn Posts tool helps you draft posts that resonate with professionals. Make an impact today!

SimpleTextGenerationWorkflow.Content Description: LinkedIn is a professional networking platform where you can share your thoughts, ideas, and experiences with your connections.Your post should be informative,engaging,and relevant to your target audience. Ensure that your post is error - free,factually correct,and follows LinkedIn community guidelines. LinkedIn Posts generally are around 100 to 200 words and not too long. The post never has any title,just the post.
SimpleTextGenerationWorkflow.General Instructions: 1. The output that you produce should be in a valid markdown format     2. The markdown should not have bold and/or italics styling     3. Validate that the markdown is correct.     4. Explicitly, dont mention any markdown in the output. 5 Do not add any extra information or comments to the output. keep it precise.
SimpleTextGenerationWorkflow.Sample:
It’s 1st of July, so here’s your checklist to finally get started on LinkedIn -
1st on the list is “profile optimization” - prep work before you start creating great content. 
✅ Click a professional picture of yourself and set it as your profile picture
✅ Banner - Your Banner should have a killer copy line that says what you do or results you have produced in the last few years and a CTA 

✅ Headline - Add a headline which is a combination of what you do, who you help, and how you help. Can also add a link in your bio (portfolio, calendly, etc)

✅ Feature section is the first clickable thing on your profile. Don’t ADD your BEST POST. Add your website link, landing page, Calednly link, published article, basically something that either tells the visitor what you do or how they can connect. 

✅ About section - If you want to keep it simple, just add a few lines about TG’s (target audience) problems, what solutions you offer, and how they can benefit from your services. The second way is to talk about your present (what you do now), your future (your vision), and your past (results you’ve brought for other clients)End it with a CTA. 

✅ Experience - Add everything you’ve done in the past (internships, part-time, freelance, full-time) and include pointers are your responsibilities, achievements, promotions, etc. 

✅ Education - Make this section also detailed. Add relevant keywords for which you want to get ranked on LinkedIn. 

✅ Skills - Add skills related to your services and get them endorsed

✅ Recommendations - Try to get a minimum of 3-4 recommendations from your colleagues, clients, or pals. This plays a huge role in building credibility.  

And voila, you’re all set to start posting now! 

Let me know if you want me to create a post on how to generate ideas for content. 

P.S - some profiles for reference 
Matt Barker 
Jasmin Alić 
Lara Acosta 
Luke Matthews 

#content #personalbranding #socialmedia #b2b #founders #linkedincontent #ghostwriter

Template.Title: Title for YouTube Video
Template.Description: Get a title your YouTube video instantly

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: Imagine you are an expert marketer. A YouTube video title is the name given to a video that is uploaded to the YouTube platform. It is the main heading that appears above the video when it is displayed on the YouTube website or mobile app.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now write a title for a YouTube video about - {{about}}. The title of a YouTube video should be descriptive and give viewers an idea of what the video is about. It should be attention-grabbing, informative, and relevant to the content of the video. A well-crafted title can help to attract viewers and improve the visibility and reach of the video.

YouTube video titles can be up to 100 characters in length, although it is recommended to keep titles around 60 characters or less for optimal readability and search engine optimization (SEO). Including relevant keywords in the title can also help to improve the discoverability of the video in search results.

Some tips for creating effective YouTube video titles include:

Keep it concise: Make sure your title is short and to the point. Aim for around 60 characters or less.

Be descriptive: Use specific and descriptive language to give viewers an idea of what the video is about.

Include relevant keywords: Include keywords that are relevant to the content of the video to improve search engine visibility.

Be attention-grabbing: Use interesting or provocative language to catch viewers' attention and encourage them to click on your video.

Avoid clickbait: While it's important to be attention-grabbing, it's also important to be honest and accurate in your titles. Avoid using misleading or clickbait titles that do not accurately represent the content of the video.

Talk to your audience and make the captions interactive and personalised. The captions should be trendy and personalised and should connect with the users. It should be either a funny , witty quote or an emotional or cute short story. It should attract the audience and keep the engaged. Add a call to Actions such as like comment or share. Keep the language simple and friendly.

Template.Title: Script for Sales Pitch

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: Imagine you are a trained sales representative/BDE. A sales script is a pre-written dialogue or set of talking points used by sales representatives or teams during the sales process. A sales script typically includes an introduction, a series of open-ended questions to uncover customer needs and pain points, and a proposed solution or product that addresses those needs. The ideal structure of a sales script may vary depending on the product or service being sold, as well as the salesperson's style and the company's sales process. However, here is a general structure that can be used as a guide:
Introduction - Make this catchy to compel the receiver to stop, listen and talk; ensure you open with professionalism but also connect with the receiver
Qualification - Ask open-ended questions to qualify the customer and uncover their needs and pain points. Provide suggestions of possible answers and rebuttal if applicable
Presentation - Present the product or service, highlighting its unique features and benefits that align with the customer's needs and pain points
Objection handling - Address any objections or concerns that the customer may have,
Close - Close the sale by using a strong call to action and creating a sense of urgency. 
Follow-up
It's important to keep in mind that a sales script should not sound robotic or rehearsed. The salesperson should be able to adapt the script to the customer's needs and communicate in a natural and conversational tone. The script should also be flexible enough to allow for improvisation and spontaneous conversation.

Specific questions: Asking specific questions can help ensure that the feedback received is relevant and useful. Avoid asking vague questions that may not provide enough information.

Open-ended questions: Open-ended questions can provide customers with the opportunity to provide detailed feedback and share their thoughts and opinions in their own words.

Multiple channels: Providing multiple channels for customers to provide feedback can increase response rates and ensure that customers can provide feedback in the way that is most convenient for them. This could include email surveys, phone surveys, online forms, or in-person interviews.

Incentives: Providing incentives, such as discounts or freebies, can motivate customers to provide feedback and increase response rates.

Timely follow-up: Following up with customers after they provide feedback can show that their input is valued and can help build a stronger relationship with them. Responding to feedback promptly can also help address any issues or concerns raised by customers.

Overall, when asking for customer feedback, it is important to make the process as easy and convenient as possible for customers, while also ensuring that the feedback received is relevant and useful for improving the business.

SimpleTextGenerationWorkflow.Sample:
Cow and Company
‘Where is the cow?’ asked the office manager.  ‘The cow?’ the junior officer responded.  ‘Yes, what else?’  ‘Oh, the cowwww . . .’  ‘I told you, two days ago.’  ‘Yes. I didn’t forget. By this eve –?’  ‘No, not evening. By noon, in the lobby.’  ‘I thought he wasn’t serious,’ said the junior officer, returning to his desk.  ‘A cow?’ the accountant responded.  ‘Yes.’  ‘A real cow?’  ‘Yes, a cow, a real cow, a living cow. Now, come with me.’  Glancing towards the main door, the junior officer spotted the office assistant sitting on his rickety stool, leisurely picking his nose. ‘Natwarlal, you also.’  Halfway down the stairs, the assistant saw the cleaner walking up counting who knows what with his fingers. He grabbed the cleaner’s hand. The cleaner didn’t seem to care about his new-found direction and now there were four of them stepping out to look for a cow.  ‘I see two cows here, every day. Today’s a holiday?’  ‘They must be at the fair.’  ‘That was last week.’  ‘Let’s look near the station.’  The station was a mile away.  ‘I have to finish the ledger balances today. Mr Pestonjee said it was urgent,’ said the accountant, his legs already moving in the opposite direction.  ‘This cow business is also for Pestonjee and it’s due by noon,’ said the junior officer.  ‘Yes, yes. No, no. See you at lunch.’  The remaining three continued their journey, the assistant periodically looking back, then towards the sky, and then at the junior officer. Twice, when the junior officer had looked his way, not for any reason other than the variations in their pacing, the assistant would begin wiping the sweat off his brow, with vigour. The sun, now overhead and blazing, overwhelmed them all.  Half a mile later, despite her many manifestations – cow milk, cow curd, cow butter, cow leather, cow dung, cow paintings, cow murals, cow sculptures, a cow temple, shops named after cows, conversations around cows, a cow cart without a cow, and a man standing on one leg, hands together, uttering cow . . . cow . . . cow . . . repeatedly, the animal in its whole earthly form was not to be seen. A group, about a dozen, had assembled around the man standing on one leg. Enquiries indicated he had been in that position for eight months, nine days and five hours.  ‘Ha! Who cares?’ said the junior officer. ‘There are such men standing on every street in Varanasi. Some even stand on their heads. My grand-uncle at the temple told us about a person who has been walking on his hands since he was six.’  ‘How old is he now?’  ‘I don’t know. My uncle died six years ago and he was eight when he heard this story. That man is still alive. Must be over one hundred years.’  ‘You don’t understand,’ said the man who had taken upon himself the duty of a spokesman for the event and was addressing all kinds of enquiries, ‘The point is not the man, it’s the crow.’  ‘The crow?’  ‘He arrived two months ago and refuses to leave the man’s side. Now he has begun to crow in chorus. He says “cow” too but in English. A few days ago an Englishman was here. He confirmed this crow was saying “cow” in English.’  At that moment the church bells pealed. It was twelve. All three, as if caught in a hypnotic trance, stepped away from the crowd and resumed their journey towards the station.  ‘There, I see one,’ the assistant shouted, pointing to a sturdy, milk-white animal busy rubbing herself against a banyan tree. Her horns were painted red.  ‘Do you see the owner?’  ‘She isn’t tied. Must be stray.’  ‘She has a bell around her neck.’  ‘Doesn’t matter. We aren’t stealing. She’ll be back in no time.’  The assistant gathered some leafy twigs from a nearby hedge. ‘Is this enough?’  ‘She won’t eat them,’ the cleaner responded.  ‘She will. There’s no time to look for grass.’  The cow looked at the leafy twigs the assistant was dangling across her eyes. When he began rubbing them on her nose she opened her mouth, then spat them out instantly.  ‘How should I tie this rope?’  ‘Around her neck, take it over her ears.’  The junior officer held the rope like a garland and advanced. The cow shook her head and the rope fell in dung. ‘Eee,’ he said.  ‘You people eat it, don’t you?’ said the assistant.  ‘Not like how you eat our cows,’ responded the officer.  They had managed to tie the rope around her neck. Meanwhile the assistant ran across to the temple’s gate to buy some grass.  ‘Two pice,’ said the old woman, her back supported by the temple wall, a pile of uneven bricks, three feet high. The word on the street was that the wall was a hasty attempt by the Brahmins to prevent further encroachment, common under the pretext of road extension programs. The remaining three walls were not built – the idea had the stamp of Brahmin austerity.  ‘Here, take one pice. You aren’t doing business anyways.’  ‘Let that be my problem. I am not going anywhere.’  ‘Take what you get old woman. Tomorrow the grass will dry up like your face.’ He threw the coin on the woman’s decrepit bamboo mat.  The cow, with the bell dangling under her neck, followed the three men. When they reached the stairs of their office, she stopped abruptly. The assistant and the cleaner began pushing her.  ‘What’s going on?’ the guard came running behind them. ‘Where are you taking that cow?’  ‘To Sir Thompson,’ said the assistant. ‘She refuses to walk up.’  The guard whacked the cow with his baton, hard. By the time they reached the second floor she had urinated on the assistant’s shirt and on the red carpet in the lobby. The junior officer laughed loudly.  ‘It’s OK for you. You people drink this, don’t you?’ said the assistant, removing his shirt midway to the toilet.  The junior officer was quiet. It was an old joke.     *     The managing director sat expansively, his legs resting on the sprawling table.  ‘What is the price of our chewing gum, Mr Pestonjee? One pice?’ He twirled his stick.  ‘Yes, sir, one pice, like paan. Everyone eats paan, rich, poor, Hindus, Muslims. Do you know the price of paan?’ asked the manager.  ‘Never quite liked it.’  ‘I don’t like it either, sir. Banerjee needs one every hour and he spits it in the corridor.’  ‘Those filthy red spots. I knew it was Banerjee.’  ‘Yes, sir. That’s him.’  ‘The first time I ate paan I felt my lungs explode.’  ‘You must have swallowed it whole, sir, instead of spitting.’  ‘Well, the English haven’t quite taken a fancy to spitting, you see.’  ‘Ha ha, will they ever? Do you know the price of paan?’ repeated the manager.  ‘No.’  ‘Just tell me?’ Rat, tat, tat, tat, tat . . . the managing director was drumming his stick against the table.  ‘One pice. Sir, we are competing with tea and paan. But chewing gum has more benefits.’  ‘Why is that?’ asked the managing director, continuing the drumming – a rhythm had evolved.  ‘Is it a symphony?’  ‘I wish. Being here it is hard for a man to follow his persuasions. What were you saying?’  ‘So I was saying, one day while walking home I stopped at the vegetable market. Beside me was a bellied man reading Bombay Samachar. It’s a wonderful newspaper, almost as good as the English –’  ‘What’s your point?’  ‘Yes, yes sir. So, he stood there reading his paper loudly like he was the –’  ‘I don’t have time for this Pestonjee.’  ‘I am coming to the point, sir. So he spits without a care in the world on my new leather chappals. That barbarian! Sorry sir, for my language. He had no manners.’  ‘So?’  ‘If he spits chewing gum, it won’t soil anything.’  ‘Chewing gum does not have tobacco, Mr Pestonjee.’  ‘But poor men will still chew it.’  ‘Pray tell me?’  ‘If they are hungry and want long-lasting flavour.’  ‘They can always keep paan in their mouth.’  ‘But then the red betel juice will drain from the sides of his lips and stain his clothes. If his clothes are stained his wife will be angry. If his wife is angry she will beat him. Instead he can chew gum all day long and everyone is happy. Also, paan makes you hungry. It is a digestive after all.’  ‘It is what?’  ‘Digestive, digestive, for the stoma—’  ‘Yes, yes. But I still think children are better disposed towards chewing gum, not men. We have a small propaganda fund for this. Why don’t you work on that? Erect a few boards near some of the schools, ten or twelve at first. Make sure the shops stock the chewing gum before the boards go up.’  ‘Sir, we should have made paan-flavoured gum instead of mint. Why will anyone waste money on chewing gum when they can steal mint from their parents –?’  ‘It’s not the taste Pestonjee, it’s the form.’  ‘Sir, in that case, why not paan-flavoured gum?’  ‘By the way, have you recalled the old label?’  ‘Why? Did someone complain about my memory?’  ‘Recalled, retrieved.’  ‘Sorry, sir. Yes, sir. I did.’  ‘Is the new label specific about the contents?’  ‘Yes, sir.’  ‘Does not contain animal products. Suitable for all vegetarians.’  ‘Yes, sir.’  ‘Good. I want this message on the poster, not just the label.’  ‘Sir, these additions will cover too much space. It’s written quite clearly on the label.’  ‘And the caption?  ‘Go Mata Ko Bhata – The chewing gum the cow mother loves.’  ‘It still sounds a bit out of place to me.’  ‘You can trust me on this, sir. I have spent quite a bit of time on the subject. What better way to get the natives to love our chewing gum than to link it to the cow? After all, it is the first chewing gum in the country.’  ‘What is that smell?’ asked the managing director, looking around.  ‘Sir, I have something that will convince you the cow is the best ambassador for our product.’  ‘What?’  ‘Here in the lobby.’  The managing director stepped out of his room. A cow stood in the lobby looking at him with big moist eyes, masticating.  ‘What is this nonsense? Is this a joke, Mr Pestonjee?’  ‘No, sir. I got her for you. To show you how she eats cud, just like chewing gum. That she deserves to be on our posters. I am going to open her mouth and show you.’  ‘Natwarlal! Open her mouth,’ the manager ordered the assistant.  ‘She might bite.’  ‘Cows don’t bite. Just open her mouth.’  The assistant put a cloth around his hands and tried to open the cow’s mouth. The cow stood still. Her saliva trickled down the assistant’s wrist towards his underarms, making him wiggle.  ‘Now shoot,’ the manager shouted at the photographer, who was called exclusively for this purpose.  ‘It is too dark,’ the photographer responded. He was a portrait sort of a person, unprepared, unenthusiastic about drama.  ‘Natwarlal! Get a torch.’  The assistant ran to the stationery room and returned with a torch. The manager flashed the torch into the cow’s mouth, which was held open by the assistant with both hands.  ‘Perfect,’ the photographer said.  ‘I want her mouth wide open,’ said the manager, then turning towards the managing director, ‘Sir! The cow chews all day long. All Hindus love cows. If we use her on our posters they will love our chewing gum.’  He flashed the torch again. The cow shook her head nervously, and then ran into the photographer and his equipment.  ‘First, get her out of here,’ shouted the managing director. ‘Clean up this mess right now! I can’t breathe. I want this place cleared, spotless, before the day ends!’ Then he left for the day.  The three were pulling the cow again. With a twist of her neck she sent them to the floor. Then she turned towards the filing room.  But the day’s mail was pending. The assistant sprinted to the dispatch room, then to the kitchen to fetch his sandals, then to the accountant to collect change, and only managed to catch his breath half a mile away at the post office, two minutes before closing time. When the assistant returned it was past 5 p.m. The office was empty. The manager was resting against the door of the records room. After the mishap with the photographer, he had run after the cow and quickly bolted the door from the outside.  ‘Is everything OK?’ the assistant asked.  ‘Come here, you idiot!’  ‘Oh no, the cow!’  The manager opened the door to the stench of cow dung. In the middle of the room, the cow sat demurely with her legs folded. In her mouth was a brown file.  ‘Which file is that?’ the manager asked.  ‘I don’t know.’  ‘Pull it.’  The assistant yanked out the half-chewed file. ‘The correspondence from the file for May, Volume 1.’  ‘From last year. No one will ask for that now. Clean all this and kick her out. I don’t care if she’s a cow.’  The manager advanced towards the cow and lifted his leg. ‘Get up, you filthy animal.’  Schlip – flop – he slid on the puddle of dung and urine and landed on his back. The assistant covered his mouth. The cow rose. She looked at the manager lying on the floor, and their eyes locked for two seconds. Her neck turned, as if embarrassed. She walked past the manager, through the doorway and down the stairs. The assistant followed her with his eyes until she disappeared into the streets.  ‘See, sir, what an intelligent animal. She knew her way out.’  ‘Only one door was open, you idiot. Get me a towel.’  ‘But still, sir. She could have pushed open the other doors.’  ‘What do we do now?’ the manager asked.  ‘Go home?’  ‘About the file!’  ‘I have a great idea. Let’s get one or two mice and leave them in the room. We will blame the mice for the file,’ responded the assistant.  ‘What if the mice destroy more files?’  ‘We will put them in a cage and say we caught them. No one comes in the records room anyway.’  ‘Banerjee will.’  ‘OK. Tomorrow I will tell Mr Banerjee I saw a mouse. Or you say you saw a mouse. What would I be doing in the records room?’  ‘No. You tell him,’ the manager said.     *     The accountant, was looking out of the window into the sari shop when the assistant came up to him.  ‘Banerjee Sir.’  The accountant looked across the street. The sari shop was popular with the city’s new women. They came from nowhere, disappeared to nowhere, their untied hair playing with the sea breeze, their midriffs exposed, accentuated by the small sleeveless blouses. Did they walk out of Dhurandhar’s portraits? Was he hiding behind a window, or in the shop, painting them?  The accountant was certain Raja Ravi Verma was the country’s greatest painter. On Friday he overheard the managing director say Dhurandhar had transcended Ravi Verma. The next day at Dhurandhar’s ‘Women in India’ exhibition at the arts school he nodded affirmingly.  ‘Banerjee Sir.’  ‘Huh . . . What is it?’  ‘Nothing . . . how is the plague in Calcutta?’  ‘There is no plague in Calcutta. Who said?’  ‘I was just asking. I saw a mouse in the records room yesterday so I thought –’  ‘There are no mice in this building.’  ‘I saw it with my own eyes.’  The assistant rushed into the records room and returned with a file.  ‘Sir, see this file. The mouse ate half of it.’  ‘Let me see. Why is this wet?’  ‘No. No. It wasn’t the mouse. There must have been a leak.’  ‘What leak?’  ‘Water.’  ‘Is it raining cats and dogs in the records room?’  ‘Cats and dogs,’ repeated the accountant with emphasis. He had learnt the new phrase last week and noted it in his diary which he filled at the rate of one page per day:   Raining Cats and Dogs   By: Jonathan Swift (1710)   Meaning: Heavy rain.   Sentence: ‘It is raining cats and dogs in Calcutta today.’  ‘And the rain made such a big hole?’ the accountant asked, as he walked towards the records room.  The assistant blocked the doorway. ‘No! It’s all OK. I must have eaten it by mistake.’  ‘Have you been drinking, Natwarlal?’  The stench in the records room hadn’t dissipated. The manager rushed to the scene. Seeing him, the assistant appeared less strained.  ‘Natwarlal. You left the cow here?’ asked the accountant.  The assistant looked at the manager, then at the accountant, and then at the manager again.  ‘You will be fined a day’s salary,’ said the accountant, ‘and repair that file.’  ‘No. But Pestonjee Sir. You –’ protested the assistant.  ‘Pestonjee Sir? Pestonjee Sir won’t save you this time. Mr Banerjee is right,’ said the manager, winking at the assistant for the second time. The assistant did not look up and walked grumpily towards the records room, mumbling to himself.     *     When the manager reached home that evening and stood at his door he saw the nameplate of the new neighbour – A.K. Hedge.  ‘Persis, you met the neighbours?’ he asked his wife when she opened the door.  ‘No. Why do you smell?’  ‘Long story.’  ‘Did you shit in your pants?’  ‘No, I fell on it.’  ‘Fell? How can you be so stupid?’  ‘It’s not my fault. It was the cow.’  ‘Don’t you look down when you walk? Always in the air. Can’t you see a cow? It’s the size of an elephant.’  ‘Did you see the neighbours?’  ‘No.’  ‘They must be from London.’  ‘How do you know?’  ‘I know. Prepare your special dhansak tomorrow. I will give some to the neighbours and introduce myself. And don’t use the steel bowl.’  The next day he covered the china bowl with aluminium foil, used for the first time since his cousin had brought it eight months ago. He tied a white ribbon around it like a bow, and felt his tie for the second time.  ‘Can I see Mr Hedge? Could I have the pleasure of meeting Mr A Hedge? Could I be pleased to meet Mr Hedge? I have come to meet Mr Hedge? I have come to meet my new neighbour Mr Hedge about whom I have only heard great things. How do you do? Delighted! Delighted! How very kind of you . . .’ he continued muttering until he pressed the neighbour’s doorbell.  ‘Mr, Mr He-Hedge please,’ said the manager.  ‘Hedge?’  ‘Yes, Mr Hedge.’  ‘No Hedge. Hedgay, Mr Hed-gay you mean, from Solapur, Bombay Province?’  ‘Hedge!’ the manager repeated.  ‘No. Mr Hedgay.’  ‘Sorry . . . I was . . . I thought . . . Thank you.’  Before the person could open the door fully, the manager scuttled down the stairs. The bowl slipped from his hands and fell. The brown gravy trickled down to form a dense puddle. Broken pieces of ceramic jutted out precariously. A large stain appeared on his new suede shoes. Only the white ribbon was safe, hanging on the handrail, far away from the mess below.     *     The pundit was at the office looking for the manager for the second time that week. People came to him, he did not go to them. But this was the third office in the neighbourhood that did not bother performing a puja. If they refused, others will refuse, even native businesses. And puja was good for everyone. The prayers, the chanting, brought luck, prosperity. After talking to fellow priests he planned to offer his services gratis. A public ceremony will send a strong signal. Expenses could be recovered later, from others.  When the assistant saw the pot-bellied man he did not even wait for him to climb all the stairs.  ‘Mr Pestonjee is not in,’ the assistant said, though the manager could be seen walking into the managing director’s room. The assistant had standing instructions. The pundit would have preferred some water and a minute to rest. But who knows where the water came from or who touched it, he thought on his way down. Saved me the climb.  The next week he was giving a sermon in a school compound across from one of the chewing gum company’s freshly painted poster. Almost impulsively he made a transition.  ‘These foreigners have no respect for our values. How can we talk about non-violence when our cows are being eaten openly?’ He pointed to the poster.  ‘That foreign product has cow’s intestines. See how shamelessly they advertise. What are you doing about it? Wearing bangles?’  ‘Does chewing gum have cow in it?’ a person whispered in the crowd.  ‘What did the Muslims do when they found their cartridges greased with pig fat? The 1857 Mutiny!’ the pundit continued.  ‘Mutiny, mutiny,’ the crowd shouted.  A day later, a newspaper headline read, ‘Cow in Chewing Gum: British Company Insults Hinduism.’  That day, a large crowd was seen gathering near the railway station. At 11 a.m. an old man walked to the gate of the company and whispered something to the guard. The guard dropped his baton, ran up the stairs, through the lobby, straight into the managing director’s room.  ‘They are coming for us.’  The manager ran from his desk.  ‘Call the police,’ the managing director said.  ‘It’s too late. They are coming for us. They are burning our posters,’ said the guard.  ‘Call the police,’ the manager said.  ‘Tell everyone to leave, now! Close the building,’ said the managing director, quickly gathering papers from the second drawer of his desk and throwing them into his briefcase.  Within minutes all of the office’s twelve employees were out and the guard had locked the gates. The managing director’s car took off first. Then bicycles moved in three directions. Some like the manager walked hurriedly through the back lanes.  A week later, on the way to the railway station to catch the train to Surat, the manager saw a young boy pull the half-burnt nameplate of the company from the gravel where it once stood. The white cow sat near the temple, healthier, busy with the unusually large bounty of grass she had received over the past week.

Set expectations: Clear expectations should be set for employees regarding their roles and responsibilities, performance standards, and the organization's goals. This helps in ensuring that employees are aware of what is expected of them and can work towards achieving those goals.

Establish performance metrics: It is important to establish performance metrics that are relevant to the organization's goals and objectives. This could include metrics such as sales targets, customer satisfaction ratings, or project completion timelines.

Conduct performance reviews: Performance reviews should be conducted regularly, based on the organization's performance management system. This could be done quarterly, monthly, or weekly, depending on the organization's culture and requirements.

Provide feedback: Feedback is a critical component of performance reviews. Managers should provide feedback that is specific, constructive, and actionable. It is important to highlight strengths and areas for improvement and work with employees to develop a plan for improvement.

Set goals: Performance reviews provide an opportunity to set performance goals for the future. These goals should be specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound. Managers should work with employees to develop a plan for achieving these goals.

Document performance reviews: It is essential to document performance reviews to ensure that there is a record of employee performance. This documentation can be used to make decisions regarding promotions, salary increases, or disciplinary actions.

Your performance review questionnaire should be detail-oriented, neatly formatted, and gives proper space for each question's answers.

The key requirements of a Performance Improvement Plan (PIP) can vary depending on the organization and the nature of the performance issue being addressed. However, some common elements of a PIP may include:

Clear and specific goals: The PIP should include clear and specific performance goals that the employee needs to achieve. These goals should be measurable, achievable, and relevant to the employee's role.

Timeline: The PIP should include a timeline for achieving the performance goals. This timeline should be reasonable and take into account the employee's workload and other responsibilities.

Support and resources: The PIP should outline the support and resources that will be provided to the employee to help them achieve the performance goals. This may include additional training, coaching, or mentoring.

Regular feedback: The PIP should include regular feedback and performance reviews to help the employee understand how they are progressing towards their goals and what improvements they need to make.

Consequences: The PIP should clearly outline the consequences if the employee does not meet the performance expectations outlined in the plan. This may include termination of employment if the employee fails to make sufficient progress.

Overall, a PIP should be a clear and actionable plan that sets out specific goals, timelines, and expectations for the employee's performance. It should be designed to help the employee improve their performance and meet the expectations of their role, while also providing a structured approach for the employer to monitor progress and take appropriate action if necessary.

Template.Title: Non Disclosure Agreements
Template.Description: Create effective NDAs for any situation

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: Imagine yourself to be a legal expert who crafts non-disclosure agreements. It is a legal contract between two or more parties that outlines confidential information that they will share with each other for a specific purpose but are obligated to keep secret and not share with others. You are required to share an NDA draft that a user can use.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
In case the output includes headings and sub-headings then
1. The output must be in a valid markdown format. For example - add a # before an H1, ## before an H2, and so on. 
2. The markdown should not have bold and italics styling.
3. Just validate that the markdown is correct and do not add anything in the output.

Now create an NDA for company - {{company_name}} being given for job role - {{job_role}}. This may include sections such as:

1. Definition of confidential information: The NDA should define the types of information that are considered confidential and protected under the agreement. This could include trade secrets, financial information, customer data, or any other sensitive information that the parties want to keep confidential.
2. Purpose of the agreement: The NDA should state the purpose for which the confidential information is being disclosed and the parties involved in the agreement.
3. Obligations of the recipient: The NDA should outline the obligations of the recipient of the confidential information. This could include requirements to keep the information confidential, to use the information only for the specified purpose, and to limit access to the information to those who have a need to know.
4. Duration of the agreement: The NDA should specify how long the agreement will remain in effect, and under what circumstances it may be terminated.
5. Consequences of breach: The NDA should outline the consequences of breach of the agreement, including any damages or other remedies that may be available.
6. Governing law: The NDA should specify the governing law that will apply to the agreement and any disputes that may arise under it.
7. Exclusions: The NDA should specify any information that is not considered confidential and is therefore excluded from the scope of the agreement.
8. Permitted Disclosures: The NDA should state any circumstances under which the recipient is permitted to disclose the confidential information. This could include situations where the information is required to be disclosed by law or to third parties who have a legitimate need to know.
9. Injunctive Relief: The NDA should specify that the disclosing party may seek injunctive relief to prevent the recipient from disclosing or using the confidential information in violation of the agreement.
10. Return or Destruction of Information: The NDA should require the recipient to return or destroy all confidential information upon termination of the agreement or at the request of the disclosing party.
11. Governing Jurisdiction: The NDA should specify the jurisdiction where any disputes arising from the agreement will be resolved.
12. Severability: The NDA should include a provision that states that if any provision of the agreement is found to be invalid or unenforceable, the remaining provisions will remain in effect.
13. Assignment: The NDA should specify whether the parties are permitted to assign or transfer their rights and obligations under the agreement to third parties.
14. Notice: The NDA should specify the procedure for giving notice under the agreement, including the address and contact information of each party.

It is important the agreement is clear, detailed, and easily accessible to users. It should be written in legal language.

Compliance and Governance: Establishing mechanisms for monitoring and ensuring compliance with the policy, assigning responsibilities, and providing guidance for internal audits or reviews.

The GDPR and Data Retention Policy serves as a guiding document for organizations to establish consistent and compliant data retention practices while safeguarding the privacy rights of individuals.

Value-Based Emails: The next few emails in the sequence provide valuable content, such as educational articles, tips, tutorials, or resources that are relevant to the subscriber's interests or the product/service you offer. Promotional Emails: As the sequence progresses, you can start incorporating promotional emails that highlight your products, services, or special offers. Call to Action (CTA) Emails: Towards the end of the sequence, you can include emails that explicitly invite the subscriber to take a specific action, such as making a purchase, signing up for a webinar, booking a consultation, or subscribing to a higher-tier service. Now write a WhatsApp message for about - {{about}}. The messages can include text, emojis, stickers, images, videos, or voice recordings.

The most important thing in a WhatsApp message is to provide clear and concise communication that delivers value to the recipient. Here are a few key aspects to consider:

Relevance: Ensure that the message is relevant to the recipient's interests, needs, or previous interactions with the organization. Tailor the content to resonate with the audience and address their specific concerns or preferences.

Clarity: Use clear and straightforward language to convey the message effectively. Avoid jargon or complex terms that may cause confusion. Be concise and get to the point quickly to maintain the recipient's attention.

Value: Offer something valuable or beneficial to the recipient. This could be important updates, exclusive offers, relevant information, or useful resources. Focus on providing solutions, addressing pain points, or fulfilling the recipient's needs.

Call to Action: Include a clear call to action that directs the recipient towards the desired action. Whether it's making a purchase, signing up for an event, or visiting a website, provide a specific and easy-to-follow instruction.

Personalization: Whenever possible, personalize the message by addressing the recipient by their name or referencing their previous interactions. Personalization helps create a sense of connection and makes the message feel more tailored to the individual.

Professionalism: Maintain a professional tone and uphold the organization's brand image. Check for spelling and grammar errors, use appropriate language, and ensure the message reflects the organization's values and tone of voice.

Template.Title: Welcome Call
Template.Description: Engage and welcome customers through phone calls

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: A Welcome Call is a type of communication made to new customers or clients to provide a warm and personalized introduction to a company or service. It is typically conducted by a representative of the company, such as a customer service agent or salesperson, shortly after a customer has made a purchase or signed up for a service
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now write a welcome call script for company - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format. The key elements of a Welcome Call include:

Introduction and Greeting: The representative initiates the call with a friendly and welcoming greeting, introducing themselves and the company they represent.

Expressing Appreciation: The representative expresses gratitude for the customer's decision to choose the company's product or service, emphasizing their value and importance as a customer.

Confirmation of Details: The representative confirms the customer's contact information, purchase details, or any relevant information associated with their account to ensure accuracy and avoid any misunderstandings.

Product or Service Overview: The representative provides a brief overview of the product or service the customer has acquired, highlighting its key features, benefits, and how it can address the customer's needs or solve their problems.

Answering Questions: The representative encourages the customer to ask any questions they may have regarding the product, service, or their overall experience. They provide clear and concise answers, addressing any concerns or uncertainties the customer may express.

Setting Expectations: The representative sets clear expectations regarding next steps, such as delivery timelines, activation processes, or additional onboarding steps that the customer may need to complete. They provide a timeline or estimated dates for any upcoming interactions or milestones.

Offering Support: The representative assures the customer that support is readily available should they need any assistance or encounter any issues along the way. They provide contact information or instructions on how to reach the company's customer service department for further assistance.

Closing and Thanking: The representative concludes the call by expressing appreciation once again for the customer's business and for taking the time to engage in the call. They offer any final assistance or information the customer may need before ending the conversation.

A Welcome Call aims to make customers feel valued, informed, and supported from the very beginning of their relationship with a company. It helps establish a positive first impression, fosters trust, and sets the stage for a strong customer experience moving forward.

Template.Title: Informational Call
Template.Description: Provide valuable information through phone calls

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: An Informational Call is a type of communication made to provide specific information, details, or updates to individuals or groups. It serves as a means to convey important information, answer questions, and address concerns.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now write an information call script for company - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format. The key elements of an Informational Call include:

Introduction and Purpose: The caller introduces themselves and states the purpose of the call, providing a brief overview of the information to be shared.

Information Delivery: The caller presents the information clearly and concisely, using a structured approach to ensure the message is easily understood. They may use visuals, examples, or supporting materials to enhance comprehension.

Addressing Questions and Concerns: The caller allows time for participants to ask questions or raise concerns related to the information being shared. They provide thoughtful responses, clarifications, and additional details as needed.

Active Listening: The caller actively listens to participants' questions, comments, and feedback, demonstrating empathy and understanding. They ensure that all concerns are addressed and that participants feel heard and valued.

Follow-up Actions: The caller outlines any follow-up actions that participants need to take based on the information provided. This may include providing additional resources, directing participants to relevant materials or websites, or scheduling future meetings or activities.

Recap and Summary: The caller summarizes the key points covered during the call, emphasizing important details and reinforcing the main message. This helps participants retain and recall the information more effectively.

Closing and Next Steps: The caller concludes the call by expressing gratitude for participants' time and attention. They provide any final instructions, contact information, or resources that may be helpful for further engagement or follow-up.

An Informational Call can be used in various contexts, such as company updates, project briefings, training sessions, or educational presentations. Its purpose is to disseminate information efficiently, promote understanding, and foster effective communication between the caller and the participants.

Template.Title: Menu Prompt Call
Template.Description: Guide customers through menu prompts in phone calls
Template.TemplatePrompt: Make menu prompt call script for

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: A Menu Prompt Call is a type of phone interaction that guides callers through a menu of options and prompts them to make selections based on their specific needs or preferences. It is commonly used in customer service, helplines, or automated phone systems.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now write an menu prompt call script for about - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format. The key elements of a Menu Prompt Call include:

Introduction and Greeting: The system or representative initiates the call with a brief greeting, welcoming the caller and introducing the purpose of the call.

Menu Options: The caller presents a series of menu options to the caller, providing a list of choices that align with the available services, departments, or inquiries. Each option is typically assigned a corresponding number or key for easy selection.

Clear Instructions: The caller provides clear and concise instructions on how to navigate the menu. This may include requesting the caller to press a specific number or key on their phone keypad to select an option.

Caller Response: The caller prompts the caller to make their selection by following the provided instructions. The caller can respond by pressing the corresponding number or key on their phone keypad.

Validation and Routing: Once the caller makes a selection, the system or representative validates the input and routes the call to the appropriate destination, such as a specific department, customer service representative, or information line.

Error Handling: If the caller makes an invalid selection or encounters an issue, the caller provides options for error correction or redirects the caller to a dedicated support line for assistance.

Repeat or Return Options: The caller offers the option to repeat the menu prompt or return to a previous menu level, allowing the caller to navigate the menu further or make a different selection.

Call Conclusion: Once the caller has successfully made their selection, the call may proceed to further interaction, such as connecting with a live representative, accessing specific information, or completing a transaction. The call may conclude with a final message or a transfer to the appropriate destination.

A Menu Prompt Call aims to provide a user-friendly and efficient way for callers to access the desired information or services by following a structured menu system. It helps streamline call routing, reduce wait times, and improve the overall customer experience by enabling self-service options and directing callers to the right resources or personnel.

Template.Title: Order Confirmation and Update Call

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: An Order Confirmation and Update Call is a phone conversation made to provide customers with confirmation of their placed orders and any relevant updates regarding their order status, delivery, or changes. It serves as a proactive communication method to keep customers informed and address any concerns they may have.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now write an order confirmation and update call script for company - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format. The key elements of an Order Confirmation and Update Call include:

Introduction and Greeting: The representative initiates the call with a warm greeting, confirming the customer's identity and introducing themselves and their role.

Order Confirmation: The representative confirms the details of the customer's order, including the products or services purchased, quantities, pricing, and any customization options. They ensure that the information aligns with the customer's expectations and address any discrepancies or clarifications.

Delivery and Shipping Information: The representative provides updates on the order's delivery status, estimated shipping or delivery dates, and any relevant tracking information. They may also explain the shipping process, carriers used, and any additional delivery options available to the customer.

Payment and Billing Information: If applicable, the representative verifies the payment details provided by the customer and confirms that the payment has been processed successfully. They address any concerns related to billing, invoicing, or payment methods and provide assistance if needed.

Order Updates and Changes: If there are any updates or changes to the customer's order, such as product availability, delays, or substitutions, the representative communicates this information clearly and transparently. They explain the reasons behind the changes and offer suitable alternatives or resolutions to ensure customer satisfaction.

Addressing Questions and Concerns: The representative allows the customer to ask questions, express concerns, or seek clarification regarding their order. They actively listen to the customer's inquiries, provide accurate and helpful responses, and offer solutions to address any issues raised.

Next Steps and Follow-up: The representative summarizes the key points discussed during the call and outlines any necessary next steps for the customer, such as confirming delivery details, providing additional documentation, or scheduling follow-up calls if required. They ensure that the customer is aware of the available support channels for further assistance.

Closing and Appreciation: The representative concludes the call by expressing appreciation for the customer's business, reiterating their commitment to customer satisfaction, and inviting the customer to reach out if they have any further questions or concerns.

An Order Confirmation and Update Call aims to provide customers with peace of mind, keep them informed about their order progress, and address any potential issues or changes promptly. It helps build trust, enhance the customer experience, and ensure a smooth and satisfactory order fulfillment process.

Template.Title: Appointment Reminder Call

Now write an appointment reminder call script for about - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format. The key elements of an Appointment Reminder Call include:

Appointment Details: The representative reminds the individual about the date, time, and location of the appointment. They may also provide any specific instructions or requirements related to the appointment, such as documents to bring, preparation needed, or any pre-appointment procedures.

Confirmation of Attendance: The representative asks the individual to confirm their attendance or availability for the appointment. They may provide alternative options or rescheduling options if the individual is unable to make it to the original appointment.

Addressing Questions and Concerns: The representative allows the individual to ask any questions or express concerns they may have regarding the appointment. They provide clear and accurate responses, addressing any uncertainties and ensuring that the individual feels well-informed and prepared.

An Appointment Reminder Call serves as a helpful tool to reduce appointment no-shows, improve attendance rates, and ensure that individuals are well-prepared and aware of their upcoming commitments. Template.Title: Payment Reminder Call

Template.Title: Customer Survey Call
Template.Description: Gather valuable feedback through phone calls
Template.TemplatePrompt: Make customer survey call script for

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: A Customer Survey Call is a phone call made to gather feedback and insights from customers regarding their experiences with a product, service, or overall satisfaction with a brand.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now write a customer survey call script for company - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format. The key elements of a Customer Survey Call include:

Introduction and Purpose: The representative initiates the call by introducing themselves and the organization they represent. They explain the purpose of the call, which is to conduct a customer survey to gather feedback and opinions.

Explanation of Survey: The representative provides a brief overview of the survey, including its objective, duration, and the types of questions that will be asked. They may mention the importance of the customer's input in improving products or services.

Consent and Assurance of Confidentiality: The representative seeks the customer's consent to participate in the survey. They assure the customer that their responses will be kept confidential and used solely for research and improvement purposes.

Survey Questions: The representative asks a series of questions based on the survey script. These questions can cover various aspects such as product satisfaction, customer service experience, brand perception, or specific areas of interest. The representative actively listens to the customer's responses and records them accurately.

Probing and Clarification: If needed, the representative may ask additional probing questions to gather more detailed or specific information. They seek clarification to ensure they fully understand the customer's feedback and opinions.

Encouragement and Engagement: The representative maintains a friendly and engaging tone throughout the call to encourage the customer's participation and open dialogue. They may express appreciation for the customer's input and provide positive reinforcement.

Thanking and Summarizing: At the end of the survey, the representative expresses gratitude for the customer's time and participation. They summarize the key points discussed during the call to ensure the accuracy of the recorded information.

Closing and Next Steps: The representative concludes the call by thanking the customer once again and informing them about any follow-up actions, if applicable. They may mention how the collected feedback will be analyzed and used to enhance products, services, or customer experiences.

A Customer Survey Call serves as a valuable tool for organizations to gather insights directly from their customers, helping them understand customer needs, identify areas for improvement, and measure customer satisfaction. The feedback obtained from these calls can guide strategic decision-making, product/service enhancements, and overall customer relationship management.

Template.Title: Customer Support Call
Template.Description: Provide customer support and assistance through phone calls
Template.TemplatePrompt: Make customer support call script for

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: A Customer Support Call is a phone call made by customers to seek assistance, information, or resolution to their product or service-related issues.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now write a customer support call script for company - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format. The key elements of a Customer Support Call include:

Greeting and Identification: The customer initiates the call and is greeted by a customer support representative who identifies themselves and the company they represent. They may ask for the customer's name and account details to personalize the interaction.

Active Listening and Empathy: The representative actively listens to the customer's concerns, questions, or issues with empathy. They demonstrate understanding and assure the customer that they are there to help resolve the problem.

Problem Diagnosis: The representative asks relevant questions to gather more information about the issue. They use active listening skills to identify the root cause of the problem and assess its severity.

Troubleshooting and Guidance: Based on the gathered information, the representative provides step-by-step instructions or guidance to help the customer troubleshoot the issue. They may explain product features, settings, or provide solutions to common problems.

Problem Resolution or Escalation: If the issue can be resolved during the call, the representative takes necessary actions to fix the problem. They may walk the customer through the troubleshooting process, suggest workarounds, or provide alternative solutions. If the issue requires further investigation or specialized support, the representative escalates the case to a higher-level support team or department.

Clear Communication: The representative communicates in a clear and concise manner, using simple language and avoiding technical jargon. They ensure that the customer understands the instructions, steps, or solutions provided.

Confirmation and Follow-up: Once the problem is resolved, the representative confirms with the customer that the issue has been resolved to their satisfaction. They may ask if the customer has any additional questions or concerns. If necessary, they provide information on follow-up actions, such as sending a confirmation email or initiating further support processes.

Closing and Feedback: The representative thanks the customer for contacting customer support and for their patience throughout the call. They invite the customer to provide feedback on their experience with the support service and may ask for suggestions to improve the overall customer support process.

A Customer Support Call aims to provide timely and effective assistance to customers, addressing their queries, concerns, or issues related to products or services. By delivering quality support, organizations can enhance customer satisfaction, build customer loyalty, and establish a positive brand image.

Template.Title: Radio Commercial
Template.Description: Promote products or services through radio advertisements

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: A Radio Commercial is an audio advertisement broadcasted on radio stations to promote a product, service, event, or brand. A Radio Commercial aims to reach a wide audience through radio broadcasting, leveraging the power of audio to convey persuasive messages and promote products or services effectively. By strategically crafting the commercial's content and engaging the listeners, businesses can generate brand awareness, attract new customers, and drive desired actions.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now write a radio commercial script for about - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format. The key elements of a Radio Commercial include:

Attention-Grabbing Opening: The commercial begins with an attention-grabbing element, such as a catchy jingle, engaging dialogue, or an intriguing statement, to capture the listeners' attention and make them curious about the message.

Clear Message: The commercial delivers a concise and clear message about the product, service, or brand being promoted. It highlights the key features, benefits, or unique selling points to create interest and persuade the listeners.

Persuasive Content: The commercial employs persuasive techniques to influence the listeners' behavior. It may include persuasive language, storytelling, testimonials, statistics, or emotional appeals to connect with the audience and convince them of the value or desirability of the offering.

Call to Action: The commercial includes a compelling call to action, prompting listeners to take a specific action. It may encourage them to visit a website, call a phone number, visit a store, make a purchase, or participate in a promotion. The call to action is clear, direct, and creates a sense of urgency or incentive for immediate action.

Branding and Contact Information: The commercial reinforces the brand identity by mentioning the brand name, slogan, or recognizable elements associated with the brand. It also provides contact information, such as a website URL, phone number, or physical address, to enable listeners to easily reach out or learn more about the product or service.

Suitable Length: The commercial is designed to fit within a specific time slot on the radio, typically ranging from a few seconds to a minute. It is concise and impactful, delivering the intended message effectively within the allocated time.

Engaging Audio Elements: The commercial utilizes engaging audio elements, such as music, sound effects, voice-overs, or character voices, to enhance the overall appeal and create a memorable listening experience. These audio elements complement the message and help in capturing the listeners' attention.

Compliance with Regulations: The commercial adheres to any legal or industry regulations regarding advertising content, including guidelines on accuracy, transparency, and ethical practices.

The document should cover the following aspects of pricing strategies:

Skimming pricing: Explain how to price the product at a high price initially, and then gradually reduce the price over time.

Conversation Flow: Aim to maintain a smooth conversation flow by actively listening and responding to the other person's messages. Avoid dominating the conversation or bombarding them with a barrage of questions. Strike a balance between sharing about yourself and showing interest in them.

Cost structure: The business model should identify and analyze the costs associated with operating the business, including fixed and variable costs, and consider ways to optimize and reduce expenses.

Template.Title: Unabridged Audiobook
Template.Description: Experience the complete book in audio format

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: An unabridged audiobook refers to a complete and unabridged version of a book that is recorded and made available in audio format. It means that the entire content of the book, including all the chapters, paragraphs, and sentences, is included in the audio recording without any abridgment or omission. Unabridged audiobooks provide the full reading experience of the original printed book, allowing listeners to enjoy the complete story, details, and nuances as intended by the author.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now, create an unabridged audiobook about - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format. The key elements and structure of an unabridged audiobook typically include:

Narrator: An experienced voice actor or professional narrator who reads the book aloud and brings the story to life through their vocal performance.

Full Text: The entire text of the book is recorded, ensuring that no parts of the original content are omitted or condensed.

Chapter Divisions: The audiobook is organized into chapters, just like the printed book, making it easy for listeners to navigate through the content.

Introductions and Forewords: If the printed book includes introductory sections or forewords, they are usually included in the audiobook as well.

Prologue and Epilogue: Similar to the printed book, an unabridged audiobook includes any prologues or epilogues that are part of the original text.

Book Sections: Non-fiction books or books with distinct sections may have these sections clearly identified and separated within the audiobook.

Reading Style: The narrator's reading style may vary depending on the genre and tone of the book. They may employ different voices for characters, convey emotions, and use appropriate pacing to maintain the listener's engagement.

The structure and presentation of an unabridged audiobook aim to replicate the reading experience of the printed book as closely as possible, providing listeners with a comprehensive and immersive storytelling experience.

Template.Title: Abridged Audiobook
Template.Description: Enjoy a condensed version of the book in audio format

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: An abridged audiobook refers to a condensed version of a book that has been edited or shortened for the audio format. Unlike an unabridged audiobook that includes the complete text of the original book, an abridged audiobook selectively omits certain sections, passages, or details to create a shorter and more streamlined version of the story.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now, create an abridged audiobook about - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format. The key elements and structure of an abridged audiobook include:

Narrator: Similar to an unabridged audiobook, an experienced voice actor or professional narrator is responsible for reading the condensed version of the book.

Edited Content: The original book is carefully edited and shortened to create a more concise narrative. Certain sections, paragraphs, or details that are deemed less essential to the main plot may be omitted.

Retained Plot: Despite the condensation, the abridged audiobook retains the core plot points and major events of the story, ensuring that listeners can follow and understand the main narrative arc.

Streamlined Storytelling: Abridged audiobooks aim to provide a streamlined storytelling experience by focusing on the essential elements of the book. Descriptions, subplots, and secondary characters may be simplified or omitted to maintain a brisk pace.

Pacing: The narration in abridged audiobooks may have a faster pace compared to unabridged versions, as the condensed content requires a more efficient delivery to cover the main story within a shorter duration.

Audio Quality: Similar to unabridged audiobooks, abridged versions strive for high audio quality, ensuring clear and professional recording without background noise or distractions.

The structure of an abridged audiobook may vary depending on the specific editing decisions made for that particular adaptation. However, the overall goal is to present a shortened yet coherent version of the original book, allowing listeners to grasp the main story and its key elements while offering a more time-efficient listening experience.

Template.Title: Multicast Audiobook
Template.Description: Experience the book with multiple narrators in audio format

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: A multicast audiobook refers to an audio production where multiple narrators collaborate to bring the story to life. Unlike a traditional audiobook with a single narrator, a multicast audiobook involves multiple voice actors, each assigned to portray different characters or sections of the book
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now write a multicast audiobook about - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format. The key elements of a multicast audiobook include:

Multiple Narrators: A multicast audiobook involves the collaboration of multiple voice actors or narrators who assume different roles within the story. Each narrator is assigned specific characters or sections to voice.

Character Differentiation: Each narrator brings a distinct voice and interpretation to the characters they portray. This helps in creating unique personalities, accents, and vocal characteristics for each character, enhancing the immersion and believability of the story.

Dialogue Interaction: With multiple narrators, the dialogue exchanges between characters can be more dynamic and authentic. The narrators can engage in back-and-forth conversations, providing a more engaging listening experience.

Narration Coordination: The narrators work together to ensure a smooth and cohesive narration. There is coordination in terms of pacing, tone, and overall delivery to maintain consistency and coherence throughout the audiobook.

Sound Effects and Music: In some multicast audiobooks, sound effects and music may be used to complement the narration and enhance the storytelling. These additional audio elements can create a more immersive and theatrical experience.

The combination of multiple narrators, character differentiation, interactive dialogue, and attention to audio production quality are the key elements that contribute to the distinctiveness of a multicast audiobook. These elements work together to create an engaging and immersive listening experience, allowing the story to come alive through the collaborative efforts of the narrators.

Template.Title: Full-Cast Audiobook
Template.Description: Engage with an ensemble cast performance in audio

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: A full-cast audiobook refers to an audio production in which multiple voice actors, or a full cast, perform the various characters and roles in a book or story. Unlike a traditional audiobook narrated by a single narrator, a full-cast audiobook brings the story to life by assigning different actors to portray the different characters, creating a more immersive and dynamic listening experience. A full-cast audiobook offers a dynamic and richly layered audio experience, particularly suited for books with multiple characters, dialogue-heavy narratives, or stories that benefit from immersive performances.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now write a full-cast audiobook about - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format.  Here are the key elements of a full-cast audiobook:

Multiple Voice Actors: A full-cast audiobook features multiple voice actors who bring the characters to life through their performances. Each actor is assigned specific roles and characters based on the story's requirements.

Character Differentiation: The voice actors use distinct voices, accents, and mannerisms to differentiate between the various characters in the book. This helps the listeners easily identify and connect with each character as they have their own unique vocal portrayal.

Dialogue Interactions: The full-cast audiobook captures the dialogue interactions between characters in a more authentic and engaging manner. The voice actors interact with each other, providing a realistic and dynamic exchange of dialogue, adding depth and realism to the storytelling.

Narration and Descriptions: Alongside the character performances, a narrator may be present in a full-cast audiobook to provide overall narration and descriptive elements. The narrator helps set the scene, provide context, and guide the listeners through the story.

Sound Effects and Music: In addition to the voice acting, a full-cast audiobook may incorporate sound effects and background music to enhance the storytelling experience. Sound effects can include environmental sounds, action sequences, or any other auditory elements that enrich the narrative. Music is used to set the mood, create atmosphere, or accentuate important moments in the story.

Immersive Production Quality: Full-cast audiobooks often have high production values to ensure a professional and immersive listening experience. The audio is carefully engineered to balance the voices, sound effects, and music, providing a polished and cohesive final product.

Chapter Transitions and Segues: The full-cast audiobook includes smooth transitions between chapters or sections, ensuring a seamless flow of the narrative. Segues may be employed to bridge different scenes or perspectives, maintaining continuity and keeping the listeners engaged.

Emotional Expressiveness: With the use of multiple voice actors, a full-cast audiobook can effectively convey a wide range of emotions. The actors' performances capture the nuances, emotions, and intentions of the characters, making the storytelling more vivid and emotionally impactful.

Enhanced Storytelling Experience: The combination of multiple voice actors, sound effects, and music elevates the storytelling experience in a full-cast audiobook. It brings the characters and the narrative to life, making the listening experience more engaging, immersive, and enjoyable.

required_input_parameters.name: About
required_input_parameters.placeholder: Mystery detective story / Young adult fiction

Template.Title: Author-Narrated Audiobook
Template.Description: Author personally narrates the book in audio format

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: An author-narrated audiobook is a unique format in which the author of a book serves as the narrator for the audio version. Instead of hiring a professional voice actor, the author takes on the role of bringing their own written work to life through their voice and storytelling style.
initialization_inputs.User Prompt:
Now write an author-narrated audiobook about - {{about}}. Remember, the text of this will be converted into an audio file and should be in a relevant format.  The key elements of the script for an author-narrated audiobook include:

Dialogue: The script includes the dialogue between characters, which captures their conversations, interactions, and exchanges throughout the story. Dialogue is an essential element in bringing the characters to life and advancing the plot.

Narration: The script includes the author's narration, which provides descriptions, exposition, and commentary to guide the listeners through the story. The narration helps set the scene, describe settings and environments, and provide insights into the characters' thoughts and emotions.

Stage Directions: The script may include stage directions to guide the author's performance. These directions indicate the tone, pace, emphasis, and other performance elements to ensure a cohesive and engaging narration.

Character Descriptions: The script may include brief descriptions of the characters, highlighting their key traits, appearances, and mannerisms. This helps the author in delivering distinct and consistent voices for each character during the narration.

Emotion and Tone: The script may include specific instructions on the emotional tone required for particular scenes or dialogue. It may indicate moments of suspense, humor, sadness, excitement, or other emotions to guide the author's performance and ensure the intended atmosphere is conveyed to the listeners.

Pronunciation Guide: If there are any unique or challenging names, words, or terms in the book, the script may include a pronunciation guide to assist the author in delivering accurate and consistent pronunciations.

Annotations or Commentary: In some cases, the script may contain annotations or commentary from the author, providing additional insights, explanations, or background information about specific passages or the overall narrative. These annotations may be used to enrich the listeners' understanding of the book.

Formatting and Structure: The script follows a clear formatting and structure, indicating chapters, sections, and breaks in the narration. It ensures a smooth flow of the story and helps the author maintain a consistent pace and rhythm throughout the audiobook.

Special Instructions: The script may include any special instructions or considerations for specific passages, such as whispered dialogue, shouted lines, or specific sound effects to be added during post-production.

Copyright and Legal Information: The script may include copyright notices, disclaimers, or legal information as required.

Template.Title: Audio Original

initialization_inputs.System Prompt: Audio Original refers to an audio content piece that is specifically created and produced for audio platforms without any prior written or printed version. Unlike adaptations or conversions from existing written materials, Audio Originals are designed to take full advantage of the audio medium, offering unique and immersive storytelling experiences.
